Package mz

Interface HeapInterface<T extends Comparable>

Type Parameters:
T - setting of a type based on which the elements can be sorted.
All Superinterfaces:
Sort<T>, SortSwap<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
Heap, IntroDPQHeap, IntroDPQSmoothHeap, IntroDPQTernaryHeap, IntroDPQWeakHeap, IntroHeap, IntroSmoothHeap, IntroTernaryHeap, IntroWeakHeap, SmoothHeap, TernaryHeap, WeakHeap
public interface HeapInterface<T extends Comparable> extends Sort<T>, SortSwap<T>
HeapInterface, containing the methods of Heap Sort to implement other classes.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Method Details

    • heapInc

      default void heapInc(T[] array)
      heapInc. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to sort an array in ascending order using a max heap.
      • The method starts by calculating the length of the array and assigning it to the variable n.
      • The first for loop iterates over the indices of the elements in the array from (n / 2 - 1) down to 0. This loop is used to build the initial max heap structure in the array. It calls a method named heapifyInc with the array, length n, and the current index i. The purpose of this call is to perform the heapification process, ensuring that the subtree rooted at index i satisfies the max heap property.
      • After the first for loop, the array is transformed into a max heap structure.
      • The second for loop starts from (n - 1) and iterates down to 1. This loop is used to extract elements from the max heap one by one and place them in their correct sorted position at the end of the array. In each iteration, it swaps the element at index 0 (the root of the max heap) with the element at index i. It then calls heapifyInc on the reduced heap (with length i) and index 0 to restore the max heap property on the remaining elements.
      • After both loops complete, the array is sorted in ascending order.
      heapInc method implements the Heap Sort algorithm to sort the given array in ascending order by transforming it into a max heap and repeatedly extracting the maximum element from the heap.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • heapifyInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • heapDec

      default void heapDec(T[] array)
      heapDec. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to sort an array in descending order using a max heap.
      • The method starts by calculating the length of the array and assigning it to the variable n.
      • The first for loop iterates over the indices of the elements in the array from (n / 2 - 1) down to 0. This loop is used to build the initial max heap structure in the array. It calls a method named heapifyDec with the array, length n, and the current index i. The purpose of this call is to perform the heapification process, ensuring that the subtree rooted at index i satisfies the max heap property.
      • After the first for loop, the array is transformed into a max heap structure.
      • The second for loop starts from (n - 1) and iterates down to 1. This loop is used to extract elements from the max heap one by one and place them in their correct sorted position at the end of the array. In each iteration, it swaps the element at index 0 (the root of the max heap) with the element at index i. It then calls heapifyDec on the reduced heap (with length i) and index 0 to restore the max heap property on the remaining elements.
      • After both loops complete, the array is sorted in ascending order.
      heapDec method implements the Heap Sort algorithm to sort the given array in descending order by transforming it into a max heap and repeatedly extracting the maximum element from the heap.

    • heapifyInc

      default void heapifyInc(T[] array, int n, int i)
      heapifyInc. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation. It takes an array of Comparable objects, the n of the array, and an index i as parameters. The purpose of this method is to rearrange the elements in the array in a way that satisfies the properties of a max heap, with the largest element at the root.
      • The method starts by calling a method named heapSplitInc with the array, n, and index i as parameters. but it likely performs a split or comparison operation within the heap structure and returns the index of the largest element among the current element i and its child elements.
      • If the largest value returned from heapSplitInc is different from the original index i, it means that the element at index i is not the largest among its child elements. In this case, the method proceeds to swap the element at index i with the element at index largest using a swap method.
      • After the swap, the method recursively calls itself with the updated index largest. This recursive call is performed to continue the heapification process downward from the new index largest. By recursively calling heapifyInc on the updated index, the method ensures that the heap property is maintained throughout the entire heap structure.
      heapifyInc method is used to transform an array into a max heap by recursively rearranging the elements based on their values and their relationships with their child elements.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      n - of the array.
      i - the current element
      See Also:
      • heapSplitInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • heapifyInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • heapSplitInc

      default int heapSplitInc(T[] array, int n, int i)
      heapSplitInc. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation. It takes an array of Comparable objects, the n of the array, and an index i as parameters. The purpose of this method is to find the index of the largest child element among the left child at index (2 * i + 1) and the right child at index (2 * i + 2) of the current element at index i.
      • The method starts by calculating the indices of the left and right child elements of the current element at index i. The left child index is (2 * i + 1), and the right child index is (2 * i + 2).
      • The method then calls a method named heapChildInc twice. The first call is with the parameters array, n, i, and left, and the second call is with the parameters array, n, largest, and right. The purpose of the heapChildInc method, compares the elements at the provided indices and returns the index of the larger element.
      • The returned values from the heapChildInc method calls are assigned to the variable largest. Since the second call to heapChildInc is performed using the updated value of largest, it means that the method is finding the largest among the three elements: the element at index i, the left child element, and the right child element.
      • Finally, the method returns the value of largest, which represents the index of the largest child element among the left and right children of the element at index i.
      heapSplitInc method is used to find the index of the largest child element among the left and right children of a given element in a heap structure.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      n - of the array.
      i - the current element
      Returns:
      the value of largest
      See Also:
      • heapChildInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • heapChildInc

      default int heapChildInc(T[] array, int n, int result, int child)
      heapChildInc, which takes an array of Comparable objects, the n of the array, a result value, and a child index as parameters. The method compares the child element of the array with the element at the result index, and if the child element is greater, it updates the result to the child index.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The if condition checks if the child index is within the valid range (less than n) and if the child element is greater than the element at the result index. If the condition is true, it means the child element is larger, so the result is updated to the child index.
      • The method returns the updated result value.
      heapChildInc it compares child elements with the result element and updates the result if a larger child is found.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      n - of the array.
      result - the current result value.
      child - the index of the child element to compare.
      Returns:
      the updated result value

    • heapChildDec

      default int heapChildDec(T[] array, int n, int result, int child)
      heapChildDec, which takes an array of Comparable objects, the n of the array, a result value, and a child index as parameters. The method compares the child element of the array with the element at the result index, and if the child element is smaller, it updates the result to the child index.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The if condition checks if the child index is within the valid range (less than n) and if the child element is smaller than the element at the result index. If the condition is true, it means the child element is small, so the result is updated to the child index.
      • The method returns the updated result value.
      heapChildDec it compares child elements with the result element and updates the result if a small child is found.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      n - of the array.
      result - the current result value.
      child - the index of the child element to compare.
      Returns:
      the updated result value.
